section.title: Overview
section.p: The NCC application preferences are maintained in a common entity called TPASystem. All the application preferences are loaded on NCC application initialization within TPASystem. These application preferences are then loaded with some default values present in the Constants file.

Description

Default: 1

This parameter allows out of sequence request to handle assume positive requests. If this parameter value is true, then it allows the requests with lower CC-Request-Number by comparing expected request number from session

row.entry: Allowed Concurrent Gy Sessions per Device

entry.p: This parameter is used to limit the number of concurrent Gy sessions allowed per device.

On receiving the request to create a new Gy session for a device, if this number is already reached then the oldest Gy session for that device is deleted (any reservations with that session are committed) and new session is created.
Default: 0 (no restriction on number of concurrent Gy sessions for each device).

Used to enable the automatic generation of IDs for subscriber model entities (Device, Account, User and Group). When this parameter is set to true, auto-generated UUIDs are stored as ID in Device, Account, User and Group entities.
The user friendly ID given in provisioning request will be stored as entity Name. These auto generated Ids (UUIDs) will not be visible in the Provisioning request/Response, EDR/CDR, Notification and Rules.

This value provides the activation priority for a Bundle On Use type of bundle.
The supported values are as follows:

li.p: DEFAULT: BOU bundle is activated when the conditions configured in the rules are met, irrespective of the actual usage.
ON_RESERVATION: BOU bundle is activated when the resources are reserved.
ON_COMMIT: BOU bundle is activated only when the actual usage is reported.

entry.p: This value provides the sorting order for usage of the Bundle On Use type of bundle.
The supported values are as follows:

li.p: DEFAULT_SORTING_ORDER: The BOU bundles are activated based on the existing CS priority order.
LEAST_PRIORITY_ORDER: The BOU bundles are activated only when no other resource is available.

Valid values are true and false.

row.entry: CDR Mapping Cache Reload Interval (In Minutes)

entry.p: Defines the time interval in minutes in which the CDR mapping cache is reloaded across different nodes. This is used to maintain the integrity of cache across different nodes.
Valid values: 1 to 2147483647
Default value: 1440
Note: This application preference applies to both charging and policy.

row.entry: Change-Plan:Subscription Scheduled Time Without Final State (in secs)

entry.p: This attribute can be used to update the configured time to delete the subscription when NCC executes ChangePlan using either Immediately with Prorating, or Immediately, or On Next Cycle mode, or IMMEDIATE_BACKDATED and the subscription does not have a final state configured for it's entity lifecycle.
The default value is 86400 secs.

row.entry: Clear session if no RG Active

Currently, the result code at command level in CCA is always set to 2001 irrespective of the result code values at MSCC level. Therefore, a new configurable boolean parameter named clear session if no RG active has been introduced in charging and its applicable only for CCAi.
If this flag is false, then the current behavior where CCA is always 2001 is followed.
If this flag is true and an active MSCC or RG does not exist for a given session, then perform the following task:
Set the MSCC level result code at command level, if only one MSCC is returned in CCAi.
Set the same error result code at command level and session is not created, if there are multiple MSCCs returned in the CCAi with the same Error Result code.
Set the result code to 2001 at command level and session is created, if there are multiple MSCCs returned in CCAi with different Error Result code.
There is no change in behavior for following cases (where CCA = 2001) irrespective of the value set for Clear session if no RG active parameter:
Event call behavior
CCRt behavior where the root level result code is set to 2001 irrespective of the MSCC result code and always terminate the session

entry.p: This attribute allows you to sort the charging service based on creation time of subscription or end-time of subscription/account when both CS have same priority (considering all CS sorting mechanisms are same for both CS).
Supported values are as follows:

li.p: ON_CREATION_TIME: If this is selected, then the charging service is sorted based on the creation time.
ON_END_TIME: If this is selected, then the charging service is sorted based on end-time/validity time of subscription or end-time of account, whichever is applicable.

entry.p: The default value is ON_CREATION_TIME.
Enable or disable the identification of in-group/out-group calls.
Valid values:

li.p: 0 - Disabled.
1 - Enabled. Only MOC call type is supported.
2 - Enabled. Both MOC and FWD call types are supported.

entry.p: Default: 0
Note: For SMS and MMS, 0 stand for disabled. Both 1 and 2 are considered as enabled.
This attribute represents the precision with which values are saved in the NCC database (DB).
The default value is 2.
For example, if the DB_PRECISION is 2, then the values till 2 decimal places are allowed, such as 999.9, 999.99. But, values with more than 2 decimal places 999.999999 are not allowed.

This parameter allows to enable Monthly Recurring Charge (MRC) to be paid for postpaid account from the account main balance. That is, when this flag is set to true, the MRC for postpaid account is charged from main balance of the account.
The default value is false.

row.entry: Default Concurrent Execution Delay for SNR

entry.p: This attribute represents the default delay required in the SNR concurrent execution.
The default delay time is 300000 milliseconds (5 mins). However, this value may vary depending on the system configuration.
This attribute represents the name of the default dynamic slicing profile.

The dynamic slicing rules are used to have different slice related values for different call conditions. These values can be either directly specified in the rule or obtained from executing a slicing algorithm. The execution of the algorithm is invoked by a rule action. Several instances of the slicing profile object can be defined.
The default value is default_profile.
This attribute represents the wait time of Re-Auth-Answer (RAA) after sending the Re-Auth-Request (RAR).
The default response time for RAA is 150 milliseconds.
This attribute represents the default response time for SNA after sending the SNR.
The default response time for SNA is 500 milliseconds.
If the value of this attribute is set to true, then the default state of the subscriber policy counters is sent in SLA.
If the value of this attribute is set to false, then the default state of subscribed policy counters is the state defined current value in the threshold profile.
For resource counter, when not used, the policy counter state will be -99. If it is used, then latest signaling sent for this counter is sent in SLR initial.
By default, the parameter value is set to false.
This parameter is used to set a value for default signalling state. This is not applicable if configuration is done correctly.
Default: -99
Defines the order in which the device is fetched based on the identifier type from the database during a call.
Valid values: IMSI, SIP_URI, NAI, PRIVATE, and E164
These values can be provided in any order, separated by commas. All five values must be provided. The values are case sensitive, that is, the values must be in upper case.
Default: IMSI, SIP_URI, NAI, PRIVATE, E164
This parameter is used to change time out (in milliseconds) of diameter request. In the SM GUI, this is a read-only. This can be edited manually in the TPA_systemProp file.
Note: This parameter applies to both charging and policy.
Default: 2990

row.entry: If this flag is true, then the TCP/IP notification with dynamic variables is sent to back-office system. If false, then the TCP/IP notification is not sent to the back-office system. The purpose of this flag is to enable or disable the TCP/IP dynamic notification feature.

entry.p: This application preference enables the possibility to add a dynamic policy counter to be attached to a resource-based device counter whose name is dependent on parameters received in an ongoing request. This counter maintains QoS for consumption from device resources.
Possible values for this flag are ENABLED and DISABLED.

If this flag is enabled, then NCC sends out Experimental-Result-Code = DIAMETER_ERROR_NO_AVAILABLE_POLICY_COUNTERS with error code 4241 in Sy-SLA for both initial and intermediate calls due to the unavailability of the policy counter name during the session due to unavailability of current Gy parameters.
With this feature enabled, virtual counters are the only counters recommended to be used in resource-based device counters.
Default value: DISABLED

This parameter is making the session info optional, which means CSM record is not created. Therefore, the mapping table is no longer used to fetch session keys. If this parameter value is false, then during update and terminate requests, device subscription Ids are mandatory. First, the device is read from the database, then sessions are fetched by Device Id.
Default value: true

If this flag is true and if available balance in resources, that is, Account (main balance) or Bucket for the current call is less than the requested cost, then granularity is ignored while rating and it depletes the resource balance.
The default value is False.
During the pending PLC and ELC execution, the tps of an SNR gets very high, around 2000 tps, which restricts providing enough space for Gy calls to run.

The reason for the high tps of SNR was that since we send SNR on group in case of PLC renewal or on reaching threshold. Therefore, if a group has 10 devices and all of them have Sy sessions established, then the SNR goes for all 10 devices.
This timer takes values in minutes and sends an SNR after a configurable time interval to delay the SNR traffic for the device associated with current call only.
It takes values in minutes and the values range from 0 minutes to 60 minutes (an hour).
Note: In case of on call lifecycle renewal, an SNR is sent for the current device and all other devices attached with same group are delayed with configured time.
This attribute represents the delta interval which ensures that a session is available for boundary case where a delay has happened from network in sending CCR-U or CCR-T on VT expiry.
The default value is 4 seconds.
The range is from 0 to 10 seconds.
If it is set to 0, then CCR authorization feature is disabled. Else CCR authorization feature is enabled.
Its value specifies the time in seconds after which the Gy session created due to CCR Authorization is closed if no further request is received for that session.
The default value is 0 and the valid range is 0-259200 (integer).
This attribute represents the inactivity duration for Gy session. Only if the Validity-Time is absent in the CCA, then this parameter is used as inactive duration.
The default value is 86400.
The range is from 0 to 259200.
During the old Gy session audit, the Gy session expiry is determined by either of the given rules:

li.p: If the Validity-Time AVP exists in CCA, then the Gy session expiry interval is equal to the VT value in Multiple Services Sequence (MSCC) and the delta value. The delta value is configured using the TPA system property GY Delta Interval For VT (seconds) that ensures a session is available for the boundary case in case there is a delay from the network in sending a CCR-U on VT expiry.

For example, if the Validity-Time in CCA is 10 seconds and GY Delta Interval For VT (seconds) is 4 seconds, then this Gy session is considered old after 14 seconds in case there is no further CCR-U or CCR-T messages received within 14 seconds.
If the Validity-Time AVP does not exist in CCA, then the Gy session expiry interval is equal to the value of TPA system property Gy Session Inactivity Duration (seconds).

entry.p: It indicates how to process the usage of Tariff-Charge_Usage AVP = 2 (UNIT_INDETERMINATE). The default value is IGNORE.
Following are the supported values:

li.p: BEFORE: The usage with Tariff-Charge-Usage AVP = 2 is added to before tariff change.
AFTER: The usage with Tariff-Charge-Usage AVP = 2 is added after tariff change.
IGNORE: The usage with Tariff-Charge-Usage = 2 is ignored.

row.entry: Ignore USU in update Reporting Reason-FINAL

entry.p: When NCC sends the DIAMETER_CREDIT_LIMIT_REACHED (4012) result code for a given MSCC, then GSU is not assigned and the session for that particular MSCC is closed. If the network sends USU AVP (with any value) in the next CCR-U for that closed MSCC, then it is rejected by NCC. The Ignore USU in update Reporting Reason-FINAL flag is used to avoid this situation.

When this flag is true and CCR-U arrives with any value of RSU or USU and the Reporting Reason = FINAL for MSCC and session does not exist for that MSCC, then a Result-Code=2001 is returned in CCA for that MSCC. The USU AVP is not considered for such request. That is, when the flag is true, the RSU and USU is ignored in CCR-U.
The RecordEventResult Tag of CDR is set to CC_NO_GSU_FOR_USU_RR_FINAL("235").
Default value: false
This flag is applicable only for Gy session calls.
Indicates how the session start time is set for IMS calls.

li.p: true - in CDRs, the session start time is set as time when CCR-I is received.
false - the session start time is set as the time when first CCR-U is received, which is also the time when the VoLTE call is answered.

entry.p: When the value set to true, the connection cost is deducted at CCR-I.
When the value set to false, the connection cost is deducted on first CCR-U.
Set delta time interval for IMS TEM-Entity expiry time.
Default value: 4
Set inactivity duration time for IMS session.
Default value: 300

row.entry: Include All Policy Counters in SNR

entry.p: This parameter is used to enable/disable whether all Policy counters can be included in SNR.
If this parameter is set to true, then while sending the SNR to PCRF, all the Policy counter(s) that are already present in the Sy session are also included in the SNR with their state.
Default: false

row.entry: Include Final Usage in BCR EDRs

entry.p: Set this parameter to not generate final billing cycle reset (BCR) before first call of the day. By default, it is generated.

To enable this feature, also set the application preferences VT Adjustment Factor (seconds) and TTC Adjustment Factor (seconds) to a value greater than zero. Set the TTC enabled flag to true. See section TTC feature configuration for more details.

DISABLED: Final BCR is generated before the first call of the day.
FIRST_CALL: Final BCR is not generated before first call of the day.
If active session is in progress, and the account/subscription BCR time is crossed by the allocated slice (VT exceeds BCR time), then lifecycle is not triggered by TEM scheduled regularly. However, TEM gets triggered by the first call of the day. This facilitates to include the total usage of billing cycle in related BCR EDRs.
LAST_DATA_CALL: Final BCR EDR processing waits for the final usage for the active data sessions, CCR-U/T or Audit.
LAST_CALL: Final BCR EDR processing waits for the final usage for all the active sessions (both data and voice sessions), for CCR-U/T or Audit. Default value: DISABLED
To disable the generation of CDR of all lifecycle actions, the system property Lifecycle CDR Logging Enabled is added.
The default value is true, which means lifecycle actions generate CDR.

Indicates a location policy counter ID whose PC status is associated with the current location of the device is globally refined. If this is not null, then when a device is created, the Location Policy Counter ID is attached to the device.
Default value is null.
Indicates a default location policy counter status when no location information or no mapping from location to PC status is found.
Default value is -99.
At certain times, when an old backup of LifeCycle TEMEntities is restored, multiple renewals start to happen in one go, and thus leading to pressurizing the db and comsvc nodes.

The default value is 5, which means that post five transitions, the LifeCycle renewals will cease and an updated TEM is created which will again be pushed to Kafka Queue. This preference has a range from 2 to 25.

This system parameter flag allows to provision a bundle or subscription with past activation time. The end time for subscription is calculated based on the timezone configured in an account and the creation time is set to the current time, that is Now even when the bundle activation date/time is in past.
Following are the options based on which the subscription end time is calculated:

li.p: Max Past LifeCycle Trigger Count is set as 0: In this case, the lifecycle considers the current time for execution and therefore, sets the start time as system current time. Only a single periodic lifecycle executes.

For example, consider a scenario where we have a subscription with 6-hour periodic lifecycle. If current date time is 11th Feb 2020, 20:00 and bundle past activation time is 10th Feb 2020,23:00, then after one periodic cycle is executed, the start time becomes 11th Feb 2020, 20:00 and end time is 12th Feb 2020, 02:00.

Max Past LifeCycle Trigger Count is set as 1: In this case, the lifecycle considers past time for execution, which is calculated by the activation time plus periodic length. The end time is calculated until it crosses the system current time and considers the start time of this cycle as start time and executes the lifecycle. Only a single periodic lifecycle executes.

For example, consider a scenario where we have a subscription with 6-hour periodic lifecycle. If current date time is 11th Feb 2020, 20:00 and bundle past activation time is 10th Feb 2020,23:00, then after one periodic cycle is executed, the start time becomes 11th Feb 2020, 17:00 and end time is 11th Feb 2020, 23:00.

Max Past LifeCycle Trigger Count is set as 2: In this case, the lifecycle considers past time for execution, which is calculated by the activation time plus periodic length. The end time is calculated until it crosses the system current time and considers the start time of this cycle as start time and executes the lifecycle. Maximum of two periodic lifecycles are executed.

For example, consider a scenario where we have a subscription with 6-hour periodic lifecycle. If current date time is 11th Feb 2020, 20:00 and bundle past activation time is 10th Feb 2020,23:00, then after two periodic cycles are executed, the start time becomes 11th Feb 2020, 11:00 or 11th Feb 2020, 17:00 and end time is 11th Feb 2020, 23:00 or 11th Feb 2020, 17:00.

entry.p: The default value is 0.
Defines the maximum number of Sy and/or NChf_SpendingLimitStatus sessions that are allowed.

li.p: If the value is 1: Only one Sy or NChf_SpendingLimitStatus session is allowed.

If the value is >1: NCC can respond to new SLR and NChf_SpendingLimitStatus requests, as well as maintain these newly created sessions, while also maintaining previously established, in-progress Sy and/or NChf_SpendingLimitStatus sessions.

entry.p: Default: 1

row.entry: Maximum Allowed Subscription For Device and Group

This parameter is used to restrict number of subscriptions allowed for Device/Group. Only active subscriptions attached to Device/Group are counted for restricting subscriptions count. For example, if the value is 2, a maximum of two subscriptions can be attached to device and a maximum of two subscriptions can be attached to group.
Default value: 0 (no restriction on number of subscriptions attached to Device/Group.
This parameter refers to the minimum interval between the VT and TTC.
New Call Start in Update or Terminate

entry.p: During migration from existing charging system to NCC, CCRu or CCRt for ongoing session on existing charging system arrives on NCC. As Gy sessions for these CCRu or CCRt do not exist on NCC, these CCRu or CCRt are rejected. To handle this case, the New Call Start in Update or Terminate attribute is introduced.
If this flag is set to true, then NCC performs the following tasks:

li.p: Accepts the CCRu or CCRt, which are active on the existing charging system and treats them as CCRi or CCRt.
Commits the used quantities which are reported in such CCRu or CCRt.

entry.p: Valid values are true and false. The default value is false.
Note: Subscription-ID AVP is a mandatory parameter to be sent in CCRU/T request from the existing charging system to NCC. Otherwise, NCC rejects the call.
If this parameter is set to true, then CDR logging for Sy interface is enabled.
Default: true

row.entry: This attribute represents the counter definition does not exist in the database. The non-policy counter exist in the database and may or may not be subscribed.

entry.p: This attribute represents the value indicating the policy counter (Sy) exists in the database not subscribed by the OCS.
This parameter is available only when the variable DEFAULT_CALL_DECISION value is true. This means that the call is allowed in case of one or more unknown policy counters.
This attribute represents whether the call is allowed or rejected in case of one or more unknown policy counters.
The policy counter identifiers which is not known by the OCS is known as unknown policy counter.
This attribute represents the time interval to check whether there is OSI change for Peer OSI audit.
The default value is 300 seconds.
The range is from 60 to 86400 seconds.

The changes in Origin-State-Id (OSI) can be detected either by a Diameter message (request or response) with a new OSI value or capabilities that exchange message from a peer containing a new OSI value.

On each application blade, the DiameterPeerManager detects the change and updates itself with the latest OSI for the peer. All application blades try to update the database with the latest OSI for the peer, but only one is successful. A part of updating the database is that the old peer entry has a timestamp indicating that a cleanup audit of it is underway starting.
The number to be appended in the peer OSI index value while saving session in the database.
The default value is 50.
The range is from 1 to 100.
This parameter indicates whether the pending lifecycle renewal is triggered by the REST or DIAMETER call. The measurement unit is seconds.
Following are the supported values:

li.p: 0: The pending lifecycle renewal feature is disabled.

1: If this flag is set as 1, then both pending lifecycle execution and call execution are executed in the same transaction. We can configure the time to execute the pending lifecycle and call execution, the default time for pending lifecycle execution is 1000 ms. First, all pending lifecycle is triggered (this action takes place in the best effort mode, which means only those lifecycles are executed, which we can execute in 1000 ms or configured time). If triggered operation take more time than 2980 ms, then all trigger operations are rollback and even call fails.

2: If this flag is set as 2, then first pending lifecycles are executed in one transaction, After execution, this transaction is closed and then the call is executed in another transaction. It is a dual transaction mode. We can configured the time to execute pending lifecycle and call execution default time for pending lifecycle execution is 1000 ms. First, all pending lifecycle is triggered (this action takes place in best effort mode, which means only those lifecycle are executed, which we can execute in 1000 ms or configured time). After executing all pending lifecycle, we first close the transaction and then to execute the call, we open new transaction. If triggered operation take more then 4980 ms, then all trigger operation is rollback and even call fails. The advantage of this approach is that if we have executed all pending lifecycle but got error during call execution, then in that case, at least lifecycles are updated successfully even if the call is failed and related data is rollback.

entry.p: This parameter value is considered in bytes and is used in rounding the bucket initial or current prorated value as per the multiplier factor.

NOTE: The bucket initial or current value is rounded as per the multiplier factor only when the bucket is of type VOLUME and Prorate Bucket Multiplier Factor is set to default value 0, which means bucket initial or current value is calculated as per the existing behaviour.

row.entry: Publish Retry Timer for TEM Scanner

entry.p: To avoid ever increasing Kafka offset and multiple retries of lifecycle and AUDIT TEM entities during the load, this attribute is introduced, which indicates a publish retry timer for lifecycle transitions and AUDIT. It specifies the interval in seconds after which a retry can be made in case of an unsuccessful attempt.
Note: A lower value means multiple retries are required and a higher value means fewer retries are required.
The default value is 300 seconds.
The range is from 300 to 28800 seconds.

This parameter is used to communicate removed Policy counter state. If this parameter has some value, for example, removed, and if a Policy counter is removed from the Device, then an SNR is sent to the PCRF with that Policy counter with policy state removed. If an acknowledgment is received from the PCRF, then the Policy counter is removed from the system. Else, it remains in the Sy session and is sent again in subsequent SNR(s) sent by Charging for any Policy counter.
This is applicable in the following scenario:

li.p: If there is no other Policy counter with the same name exists for the Device.
If the Policy Bucket/Counter is part of a subscription.

Policy counter is removed means a subscription lifecycle is transiting to final state from its Lifecycle. The transition from Barred to Final state has a Send-SNR action with Policy Counter name and its state is same as configured in application preference Removed Signalling State Value. It is recommended to have lifecycle of each subscription to have barred and final state defined.

entry.p: Default: Null
If this flag is enabled with indication of location or timezone change, then OCS is re-rated based on stored location updates.
Default: false

row.entry:
This attribute represents the rounding mode for calculations done in the rating engine.
Supported values are: Up, Down, Ceiling, Floor, Half_Up, Half_Down, Half_even, Unnecesary.
Default: Ceiling

This attribute represents the rounding mode for values stored in the database. This parameter is used for rounding decimals while storing them in database.
Supported values are: Up, Down, Ceiling, Floor, Half_Up, Half_Down, Half_even, Unnecesary.
Default: Ceiling
Scheduled transition time update buffer interval (in seconds)

entry.p: A buffer time interval (default 60 seconds and configurable) added in the current system time when the new scheduled time (either by using SET or DECR operation) is near the current system time. This time is added to consider TEM scanner interval time (currently 500 ms) and system processing time under load and other system conditions.
The default value is 60 seconds.

row.entry: This attribute represents the time period after which the service definition cache refreshes itself.

entry.p: This determines the pacing at which SNRs should be throttled. This decides how many SNRs should be sent in one burst and the time interval between two consecutive bursts.
Number of SNRs in one burst = SNR Scheduler Rate / SNR Pacing factor.
Time interval between two consecutive bursts (in milliseconds) = 1000 / SNR Pacing factor
Default value: 1
The value should be >= 1.
This value, if changed, needs application restart to come into effect.
This parameter is used to define the SNR message timeout in milliseconds.
Default value: 5000
This value, if changed, is updated at run time and comes into effect without application restart.

row.entry: SNR Scheduler Rate (max outbound messages per second)

entry.p: This parameter indicates whether SNR throttling is enabled.
Valid values:

li.p: If this value is 0, it means that throttling is disabled.
If the value > 0, it means that throttling is enabled, and maximum number of outbound SNRs are allowed per second.

entry.p: Default value: 0
If changed, this value is updated at run time, that is, it comes into effect without application restart. The value should be >= 0.
If this flag is set to True, then step-up fee is deducted from the account balance on committing the actual usage.
If this flag is set to False, then the step-up fee is deducted from the account when units are reserved for the call.
If this flag is enabled, it stores location details in GY calls.
Default: false
This attribute is used by the NCC application to represent the inactivity duration for a charging Sy session.
The default value is 86400 seconds.
The range is from 0 to 259200 seconds.
The reason for taking this attribute in seconds is granularity which is used in charging.
This attribute represents the base value in percentage threshold profile. Possible values are INDIVIDUAL and CUMULATIVE.

If the value is INDIVIDUAL, then only the main bucket initial value is used to calculate the threshold percentage value. If the value is CUMULATIVE, then the cumulative value of main and carry-over bucket is used.
The default value is INDIVIDUAL.

row.entry: Time Interval for PPC in SY

entry.p: If the policy counter end date is less than the current time of SLR/SNR plus the number of hours configured in this attribute, then the Pending Policy counter information is sent in the SLA/SNR.

Example: If the Policy Counter End Date: 1 Jan 2018 18:00 GMT, attribute value: 3 hours, current time of SLA/SNR: 1 Jan 2018 16:00 GMT, then while processing SLA/SNR, the policy counter expires before the current time, that is 1 Jan 2018 16:00 + 3 hours.

row.entry: Timer for invoking SOAP API after sendRAR in milliseconds

entry.p: For Real-time update query, when a query request comes, RAR is sent for all relevant sessions. NCC waits for timer assuming that all CCRs arrive. After the timer expiry, latest data is queried from DB. The value of this timer can be configured.
The default value is 3000 milliseconds.

row.entry: If this parameter is set to true, then in CCAi sends all the triggers armed by NCC.

entry.p: This parameter is defined in milliseconds and is applicable only to Diameter trigger.

It is used to manage the time taken by pending lifecycle triggers at each step in the best effort mode. For example, if configured timer value is 1000 ms for four pending lifecycle triggers (a, b, c, and d) but within the time frame of 1000 ms, the system is able to execute only trigger a and b, then in that case, trigger c and d are skipped and the system continues with the call processing.
Note: The measurement unit in milliseconds and this value should be less then 5000 ms.
This parameter is used to randomize the TTC value present in returned CCA message. This is done to ease out the time change processing on the PGW.
The measurement unit is seconds and the default value is 0.

row.entry: This parameter refers to the upper bound or higher limit of TTC Adjustment Factor when VT is set to TTC + Min Spread (seconds) as per the computation.

If this flag is enabled, then all the steps of step-bucket are consumed before moving to next resource even when some resource is available for usage.
Default: false
Example: Consider that charging services are sorted in the following order.CS 10; CS2 10, 20, 30; CS3 10 (CS2 has step-bucket). The consumption of step-bucket depends on the value set for Use All Steps First flag as follows:
If Use All Steps First flag is set to true, then move from CS2.Step1 to CS2.Step2.
If Use All Steps First flag is set to false, then move from CS2.Step1 to CS3 (Default behavior).

entry.p: If this flag is enabled, it uses location stored in device DB in IMS calls.
Default: false
This system parameter is created to keep the rating group reference, which is used to identify the ViLTE call over Gy interface.

This parameter is also considered to enable or disable VoLTE or ViLTE correlation support over Diameter 4G interface. If this parameter is set as -1, then the VoLTE or ViLTE correlation support is disabled. Otherwise, this correlation support is enabled and the configured value is considered as the rating group of ViLTE call.
The maximum value allowed for this attribute is 4294967295.
Default value: -1
This parameter is used to enable virtual Policy counter support. To enable the feature, set the value to BUCKET_COUNTER.
Default: DISABLED

This parameter is used to randomize the VT value present in returned CCA message for GY session. This is done to distribute the CCR traffic within a fixed interval range after BCR date, thus avoiding the traffic storm.
The measurement unit is seconds and the default value is 0.
This parameter is used to shorten the VT Adjustment Factor (seconds), which is used when TTC is not send in case of prepaid accounts.
Note: This parameter is only applicable to prepaid accounts.

li.p: If the OCS is configured to reject the request provided with unknown policy counter identifiers, and if OCS determines that one or more policy counter identifiers are unknown, then the OCS returns a response with the Experimental-Result-Code AVP set to DIAMETER_ERROR_UNKNOWN POLICY_COUNTERS.

section.note: To change the default value, log into the Service Manager Graphical User Interface (SM GUI). Navigate to Global configuration > Application Preferences and select Managed Elements from the hamburger menu. ( ). This opens the ME Application Preferences window from where you can select the required Managed Element (ME) from the drop-down list. Only the configured application preferences for ME that you need to work appears in the SM GUI.
